channel.title: BBC News - Science & Environment

item.title: Large hadron collider: A revamp that could revolutionise physics
item.description: The BBC gets an exclusive look at the upgraded machine helping to overhaul our understanding of the Universe.

item.title: Many protected areas do not benefit wildlife, study says
item.description: Simply designating an area as "for nature" does not mean it is beneficial for wildlife, researchers find.

item.title: Sir David Attenborough named Champion of the Earth by UN
item.description: The broadcaster is recognised for his devotion to telling stories about the natural world.

item.title: Climate change and farming driving insect decline
item.description: Combined pressures of global heating and farming can halve insect populations in some places - study.

item.title: Cambridge University study finds Anglo-Saxon kings were mostly vegetarian
item.description: Peasants occasionally hosted lavish meat feasts for their rulers, researchers say.

item.title: 'I felt more joy than I thought possible'
item.description: How it feels to treat your depression with a hallucinogenic drug.

item.title: Climate change: Key UN finding widely misinterpreted
item.description: Suggestions emissions could rise for another three years without dangerous warming are wrong, scientists say.

item.title: Scientists map Caribbean coral reefs to tackle climate change
item.description: Scientists map coral reefs in the Caribbean to identify those most likely to survive climate change.

item.title: Scientists appeal to trace meteorite near Shrewsbury
item.description: The UK Fireball Alliance believes the space rock landed in Shropshire last week.

item.title: Climate change: COP26 promises will hold warming under 2C
item.description: Scientists say their analysis is "encouraging" but keeping under 1.5C this century looks unlikely.

item.title: Nasa scientists spy 'largest comet ever seen'
item.description: It's 85 miles wide, which is larger than the US state of Rhode Island. And it's coming this way.

item.title: Mutations across species reveal clues to ageing
item.description: "Staggering" findings from studying 16 mammals - including humans - sheds light on why we age.

item.title: NZ professor snorkels over Tonga volcano
item.description: Shane Cronin gets a close-up view of the underwater volcano that erupted spectacularly in January.

item.title: Australia's koalas: Freeze sperm to save species, say researchers
item.description: Bushfires have killed many thousands of the marsupials, who are threatened with extinction.

item.title: Climate Check
item.description: As the world's temperature warms, severe rainfall events are becoming more likely - and weather patterns like La NiÃ±a could be disrupted.

item.title: Cumbria coal mine: What is the controversy about?
item.description: Cumbrian councillors are reviewing their support for a controversial coal mine near Whitehaven.

item.title: Climate change: Wind and solar reach milestone as demand surges
item.description: Wind turbines and solar panels produced 10% of global electricity in 2021 but coal also had a resurgence.

item.title: Climate change: Heatwave temperature threshold raised in England by Met Office
item.description: As the UK's climate warms, the temperature threshold in eight counties is raised by the Met Office.

item.title: Solar farms: Can expansion overcome Tory MPs' concerns?
item.description: Ministers hope solar farms can vary the UK's energy mix - but they face increasing local opposition.

item.title: Climate change: Can the Russian energy crisis help to curb global heating?
item.description: An energy strategy is due - but can it get the UK off Russian gas, cut bills and help the environment?

item.title: Axiom-1: First all-private crew launches to space station
item.description: Four men leave Earth on a commercial mission to spend eight days at the orbiting platform.

item.title: OneWeb to fly on competitor SpaceX's rockets
item.description: The London-based satellite internet firm turns to its US rival to get its spacecraft into orbit.

item.title: Scientists claim hairy black holes explain Hawking paradox
item.description: Researchers say they have solved one of science's biggest paradoxes, first identified by Prof Stephen Hawking.
